text: Continued growth requires continual gain of energy and continual radiation of heat.
At shorter wavelengths (X-rays), chemical bonds are broken indiscriminately; at longer wavelengths (microwaves and radio waves), the quantum energy is too low to drive chemical reactions.
Microbial and plant photosynthesis generates biomass, which is catabolized by consumers and decomposers.
The consumers store a small fraction of their energy in biomass.
We see this release of heat, for example, in Similarly, throughout Earth’s biosphere, the total metabolism of all life must dissipate energy as heat.
In other words, the local, temporary gain of energy enables a cell to grow.
But all sources of energy pose the challenges of how to obtain the energy, how to avoid losing it, and how to convert it for cell growth and function.
The fraction captured is largely in the range of visible light (Fig. 13.4), the wavelengths at which photon energies are appropriate for the controlled formation and dissociation of molecular bonds.
Biological heat production is not always obvious, because soil and water provide a tremendous heat sink.
At each successive level, the majority of energy is lost, radiated from Earth as heat.
As solar radiation reaches Earth, a small fraction is captured by photosynthetic microbes and plants.
But overall, Earth’s biosphere behaves as a giant thermal reactor (Fig. 13.3).
Some bacteria conduct photosynthesis using ultraviolet and near-infrared radiation.
Phototrophy and lithotrophy are discussed in Chapter 14.
The complex roles of microbial metabolism in global ecosystems are discussed in Chapters 21 and 22.
Thus, despite the growth of living organisms on Earth, the universe as a whole becomes more disordered.
proteobacteria, practice photoheterotrophy, in which energy from light supplements chemotrophy.
